questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 35 days?
questions.explanation:
Citrate dextrose phosphate adenine-1 (CDPA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days. It 
helps in improving ATP synthesis during storage. Hence, it increases the shelf life. 449 
Sold by @itachibot The disadvantage of using CDPA-1 is that it increases uric acid stone formation. The shelf life of storage with other components are: • Acid Citrate dextrose – 21 days • Citrate-phosphate dextrose – 21 days

questions.question: Question 3: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank?

options.a: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.
options.b: It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
options.c: No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
options.d: It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.explanation:
Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving. Principles of blood administration: • All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a 
filter. • A careful aseptic technique should be practised at all times. • Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the 
first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation 
to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be 
increased. • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused 
and on the patient’s cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not 
recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room 
temperature. • No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a 
blood product. • Ringer’s lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product 
because the calcium present leads to coagulation. • After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of 
the patient’s chart.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following patients receiving blood transfusions are more prone to develop 
bacterial sepsis?

options.a: A young women with severe anaemia

questions.explanation:
Patients with thrombocytopenia receiving blood transfusions (platelets) are more prone to develop 
bacterial sepsis. Sepsis is mostly due to significant bacterial contamination of the blood products. Platelets have 
the maximum risk of causing this condition when compared to red cell preparations. Since 
patients with thrombocytopenia receive platelet transfusion, they are at an increased risk of 
infections. Platelets (unlike red cells) must be stored at room temperature. This is a condition that 
is favourable for bacterial proliferation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics must be started while waiting 
for the culture reports. The blood components that are preferred for the other conditions are: 450 
Sold by @itachibot • Anaemia - RBCs • Hemophilia - FFP • vonWillebrand disease - cryoprecipitate

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. 
Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given?
questions.explanation:
Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) from AB blood group can be given to this patient as it is the universal 
plasma donor. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood 
group. O Rh-negative blood is the universal blood donor. It is used during emergency packed cell blood 
transfusion with an unknown blood group. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh 
antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s 
blood.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common reaction occurring in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.explanation: The most common blood transfusion reaction is the febrile nonhemolytic reaction.

questions.question:
Question 7: Blood transfusion was started in a patient with severe anaemia. Within a few minutes she 
developed generalised pruritis, swelling of the tongue and stridor. Which antibody deficiency 
in the recipient most commonly causes this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe, potentially fatal, allergic reactions. These are 
most likely to occur in patients with IgA deficiency. Such reactions may occur when blood products containing certain antigens are given to previously 
sensitized recipients. It is triggered by recipient IgG antibodies that recognize IgA in the infused 
blood product.

questions.question:
Question 8: Following blood transfusion in a post-operative patient, the following finding was noted. 
Which of the following is responsible for this reaction? 446 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image, showing a raised and erythematous lesion, is suggestive of urticaria. Such 
reactions may be triggered by the presence of an allergen in the donated blood product that is 
recognized by IgE antibodies in the recipient. These are mild reactions occurring more commonly in 1% to 3% of transfusions.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with thalassemia developed pallor and dizziness 1 week following blood transfusion. 
His lab reports are given below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?

options.a: Direct coombs test negative, IgG mediated
options.b: Direct Coombs test positive, IgG mediated
options.c: Direct coombs test negative, IgM mediated
options.d: Direct coombs test positive, IgM mediated

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed hemolytic reaction following blood transfusion. 
It is IgG mediated and gives a positive result in direct Coombs test. 451 
Sold by @itachibot These antibodies recognize foreign protein red cell antigens in a previously sensitized recipient 
(through a prior blood transfusion). They present with laboratory features of hemolysis like 
low haptoglobin level and elevated LDH. Acute hemolytic reactions are usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells 
that fix complement. The direct Coombs test is usually positive.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient who was admitted for blood transfusion developed transfusion-related acute lung 
injury. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

options.a: Pre-existing lung diseases are a risk factor
options.b: Incidence with platelet transfusion is more than that with whole blood
options.c: Symptoms develop after 2 days of transfusion
options.d: Subsequent transfusions from the same donor increases the incidence

questions.explanation:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs 
during or soon after the transfusion. It occurs within 6 hours, and not after 2 days following 
transfusion. TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The incidence of TRALI is low (1 per 
10,000 transfusions). However, it may occur more frequently in patients with preexisting lung 
disease. The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis: • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature 
of the lung • Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood 
product activates the primed neutrophils TRALI can occur in transfusions with all plasma-containing blood products. However, it is more 
likely to occur following the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets. This is because 
these products contain high levels of donor antibodies. Note: TRALI is important to recognize because donor products that induce complications in one 
patient are much more likely to do so in a second. Indeed, recent measures to exclude 
multiparous women from plasma donation have resulted in reduced incidence of TRALI. 452 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 33-year-old man is receiving massive blood transfusion following a fall from height. 4 hours 
after transfusion, he becomes breathless and oxygen saturation decreases. Chest X-ray shows 
diffuse bilateral lung infiltrates. Which of the following statements is false regarding this 
condition?

options.b: Treatment involves discontinuation of blood transfusion
options.d: It is mediated by macrophages in lung vasculature

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury). It is 
mediated by neutrophils entrapped in the lung vasculature. Features of TRALI are: • Fever • Hypotension • Hypoxemia • Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates - not responsive to diuretics Treatment is mainly supportive and blood transfusions are discontinued. The mortality rate in 
this condition is 5-10%.

questions.question:
Question 12: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions 
were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the 
midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP - 180/120 mmHg 
and pulse rate - 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). TACO is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This 
condition is characterized by: • Dyspnea with O2% <90 at room air • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray • Systolic hypertension • Elevation of brain natriuretic peptide, 1.5 times that of pre-transfusion levels It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly, at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of 
body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during 
this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease 
the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such 
reactions can be prevented by using leukoreduced RBCs. Removal of leukocytes from the blood is called leukoreduction. It is done before storage to 
prevent cytokine formation. FNHTR may occur due to the following: • Sensitization to the WBC antigens by previous blood transfusions or pregnancy • Cytokines produced by the donor leukocytes during storage • Bacterial contamination Note: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent, a receptor fusion protein consisting of a 
modified extracellular domain of human activin receptor type-2B linked to the human Ig-G1 Fc 
domain. The drug was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of transfusion-dependent 453 
Sold by @itachibot thalassemia. 454 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)
